ygData.subject: Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, that s a good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There are many considerations, and although I may not hit all of them, I think in general it can

Jeff, that's a good thought experiment for testing my claim.  There
are man=
y considerations, and although I may not hit all of them, I
think in genera=
l it can be refuted:

Generally, I think HyperNEAT (i.e. NEAT with CPPNs) a=
lready
approximately follow the scenario that you outline:  It discovers ke=
y
motifs (whether they be skin or something else) early in evolution and
th=
en as the overall body plan is deformed, the original motifs are
often pres=
erved (which again includes skin).  The main idea is that
skin is like a ki=
nd of surrounding motif for the overall shape, and if
the pverall shape is =
warped through some kind of mutation in the
internal CPPN, then however the=
 shape is surrounded will naturally
warp in the same way.

In fact, you can=
 see this happen consistently in Picbreeder.  It is
possible to consider th=
e simple black outline of many of the color
figures as a "skin."  You can n=
otice that it is special by noting that
often the outer band is black but e=
verything structure inside is
color.  Then, if the shape of the overall ima=
ge warps, so does the
outer membrane.

However, you might say that such a "=
skin" is not complex enough to be
convincing.  Perhaps skin should have mul=
tiple parts, i.e. its own
special structure.  In fact, if you look closely,=
 you can find many
such examples.  For example, there are often double-laye=
r outer
membranes that form, such as in this image:

http://picbreeder.org/=
search/showgenome.php?sid=3D317

There is a clear outer structure that surr=
ounds the complex curvature
of the object.

Or, perhaps more interestingly,=
 you can get several layers of color
bands, but only on the outer membrane,=
 such as in this image that ends
in a light blue that becomes green, then b=
ecomes yellow, before
sinking into the inner-body color of orange:

http://=
picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D4227

To show that the outer mem=
brane warps easily and naturally regardless
of shape changes (even complex =
ones), I further evolved that image to
get a new shape, and you can see tha=
t the outer membrane has the same
motif nevertheless, nicely warped to acco=
mmodate the new overall shape:

http://picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php=
?sid=3D5635

It is also important to note that outer membranes in nature ar=
e not
uniform covers and often transition into something else on the
surfac=
e.  For example, consider lips and eyes.  Or perhaps even more
importantly,=
 consider fingernails, where the outer cover actually
falls *under* somethi=
ng else (i.e. the nail), violating the covering
rule.  I point these except=
ions out because in Picbreeder you also
often see almost consistent outer m=
otifs that are broken in a couple
places.  While these locations often are =
arbitrary, the point is that
such a capability could be exploited if it act=
ually mattered.

Moving from 2-D to 3-D should not matter in the case of sk=
in, just as
moving CPPNs from 2-D to 4-D continues to allow all the same
re=
gularities.  So when you see examples in 2-D, they are also possible
in 3-D=
 for the same reasons.

Most of these outer skin motifs can arise early whe=
n the shape is
simple and are then easily preserved.  However, they are not=
 always
preserved.  For example, the multicolor skin above evolved into a
d=
ifferent multicolor skin in one lineage:

http://picbreeder.org/search/show=
genome.php?sid=3D4228

This phenomenon is expected from the analogy with na=
ture, just as
scales can evolve into fur, or fur into uncovered skin, all s=
till
serving the role of outer membrane.

I think it's important to note th=
at skin or an outer membrane is not
really any different from any other CPP=
N-generated motif, in that it
can be preserved, warped, or changed in its i=
nternal structure.  So I
don't think there is really anything special going=
 on in the argument
compared to the discovery of symmetry or other conventi=
ons.

ken 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Hello all-
> 
> Ken has challenged us all many times to think about whethe=
r there is any
> need for a process of development. The identity of cells i=
n
developmental
> processes is determined by local contextual information w=
hereas Ken
> advocates skipping that by letting cells determine their ident=
ity
via giving
> them their objective coordinates. The question is whether =
we lose
anything
> important to the evolution of complexity by skipping thi=
s step.
> 
> I think it is a fascinating question and, unable to come up wi=
th a good
> reason why development matters myself, but wanting to give the
=
argument a
> rigorous evaluation, I have been asking many people in our fie=
ld whether
> they can describe something unique that a developmental proces=
s
provides. No
> one has come up with  a reason that compels me, so I have =
become a
strong
> advocate of the lack of a need for an unfolding process.
=
> 
> However, in the course of watching a keynote on development in natural=

> systems at this year's gecco, an argument in favor of development
occurr=
ed
> to me that may have merit. I am interested to hear what y'all think
of=
 it.
> 
> The argument is this: it might be easier to evolve certain large-=
scale
> properties when the organism is simple and small and then scale/gro=
w
them
> up, rather than incorporating them into an already complex phenoty=
pe. I
> think an example illustrates the point best. Imagine evolution
figu=
ring out
> how to put a coat of skin on an organism. It is not that hard to=

figure out
> what the shape of that skin should be when the embryo has onl=
y a few
cells.
> Once that simple and small coat of skin has formed, it can=
 follow
the simple
> rule of keeping the layer of skin the same thickness, =
and adding cells
> within that layer to grow to cover any arbitrary shape t=
hat the
phenotype
> becomes. This simple rule could produce a skin shell fo=
r a bat or a
jaguar.
> Now consider how hard it would be for 3D hyperneat t=
o create a skin
shell
> for a bat or a jaguar. The mathematical function to=
 create such
outlines is
> very complex (although it is less so if it is a =
composition of other,
> already created functions that produced the rest of=
 the body). Still, it
> seems that this task might be harder for hyperneat =
than following
the simple
> developmental rules outlined above.
> 
> What d=
o you think? I would happily be convinced that this argument is
> without m=
erit, so please let me know if you see any problems with it.
> 
> 
> Cheers=
,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> 
> j=
clune@...
>
